The place is a little dirty, it gets really busy and they have short business hours. What they lack in these areas, they make up with taste, quantity and price! Be sure to know their business hours and be prepared to take a nap or run a marathon after you eat there.
author: Richard B. F.

description:
So this place is a hole in the wall. Definitely reminds me of those little cafes back in the PI with it's cheap tile and graffiti on the walls. I wasn't expecting much based on the looks and low prices but it had an avg of 4 stars on Yelp. It's not the French Laundry but my mind was seriously blown away at how delicious the food was for such a simple meal. I've paid $10-$20 for meals like this at food trucks and this little place blows them all away.

oh yeah, Don't be turned off by the looks. The health inspection rating is 96/100.
author: Berto A.

description:
Super cheap good food coming from a hole in the wall. Workers are chinese, serving filipino food -- odd combo but food is food. 

garlic fried rice is always on point, never changes
i usually get tocino or HK porkchop. 


the counter has a looooad of coins (looks like the toothfairy stopped by :D) LOL
Place is super janky looking, order food and take it togo. 

PS!! this is not a first-date place, just to let you know. you're welcome. :)
author: jennifer f.

description:
Food for 5 people for $16 bucks?! Hell Yeah!!

4 Tosilogs + 1 Tapsilog = 5 Happy Campers, 'nuf said!
author: Sheena S.

description: Food was cheap and delicious and that's pretty much the draw to this place. 4 stars just because its so cramped and not the most hygienic restaurant you'd hope for.
author: Sanz E.

description:
I'm not really prissy when it comes to restaurants but the first time I was in this restaurant, I misjudged the interior and walked out 5 seconds later. That was a big mistake! Thanks to Yelp's health score, i gave it another shot and I've been coming here for filipino breakfast ever since.

Cheap yet good quality food, fast and friendly service, and a quick fix for my silog cravings. For the price of a frapp, you can get a full meal in this hole in the wall fil-chi resto! And yeah, Chinese folks cooking authentic silog dishes makes it more interesting.
author: Michaella A.

description:
The only reason I wouldn't write a 5 for this restaurant is because of the actual restaurant itself. The restaurant was filthy and had virtually no space to sit. The kitchen looked dirty and the rice in the back just sat in tubs near the bathroom.

But why give a four!? Because the food was great! The food, I believe, had very good quality for the price. It's definitely worth a quick lunch to eat for the cheap price. They give very hearty portions of food and the cashier and waitress were very nice even though they probably didn't know english. It's definitely worth the title of Hole in the Wall, and if you don't mind the kinda filthy locale but excellent food, than this is the place. Obviously they go through food inspections like everyone else lol. A definite place to go for a cheap lunch with a very hearty portion :)
author: Brian S.

description: It's my guilty pleasure, I exclusively get the hong kong style pork. But I have tried the jumbo fried chicken, both are equally good I just prefer the hong style pork. The main reason I come here is I can get a meal for under $5.
author: alan n.

description:
This place is pretty cooool! My friend brought me here one day and I am very grateful for it. She explained that this place is a hole-in-the-wall Chinese/Filipino restaurant, which it is, that serves good Filipino food -- the owners are Chinese but apparently they grew up in the Philippines and they speak Tagalo! Very interesting right? I personally thought so.

Friendly staff, decent food for very low prices (bfast w/ tea or coffee could be from 3-5$!) -- overall, this place is very casual friendly place! This goes really well with the seemingly friendly neighborhood that it is located in. 

 I most definitely recommend coming here and at least trying their food! Try the tosilog :]
author: Michael N.

description: Legendary hole in the wall. 3.95 3.95!!!! Hong Kong pork chop can feed 2 people. The garlic rice is hella bomb! If you ever get a chance stop here. Great food greater prices!
author: Zachary W.

description:
OMG SO CHEAP, so good and fresh!! I can't believe a place like this existed!!! For less than $ 4.50, you get enough food for TWO meals!! I ordered the HK style pork chops, it wasn't greasy, just right! I would definitely come back for more!! 

The owners and waitress was very nice too! It's self service, but I also tipped the old lady who was the waitress serving and chatting with me. :)
author: Sophie L.

description: This is a hole in the wall place that is filling and doesn't dent your pockets. I love this place! I've been going here since I was about 14 years old. I'm in my 30's and I still love it the same. I would've expected them to change the paint or do some kind of extravagant overhaul on the building. But it still looks the same as it did when I first went there, suspect lol! But i truly love it here and the staff is very nice and have always made me feel welcomed. I love the bansilog (fried bangus fish) and tocsilog, mmm love it
author: Oluyemi O.

description:
This place is what it is. 

What is it you ask? 

Cheap and Tastey.

 One of my Filipino coworkers who grew up in SF brought me here and i was a little nervous since the place was messy as hell but i look at it like this: FAMILY BUSINESS my kind of place! Oh and just FYI don't get the fish!
author: Matteo C.

description: Love this place. I always get longsilog or pork chops hong kong style. The definition of comfort food. Everyone that I've introduce to this place to have become loyal customers.
author: Tina F.

description: Hongkong porkchop! YUM! On Saturday morning when you are craving for Filipino food this is the place to go. Most of the food here are good!
author: Beverly C.

description: Love this place, reminds me of the Philippines because the food tastes just as good as in the Philippines. I always order the smoked bangus, my favorite boneless fish! Plus it's hella cheap!
author: Carina L.

description:
Yummy! 

Another place that looks grimy on the outside but is hella good on the inside! It is on mission so most places look a little old and run down. 
Parking was easy for us and it was around lunch time on Saturday! 


I have heard a few people I know talk about this place, so I was looking forward to go. There was a line out the door when I went, but it moved fast! Everything looked and smelt great when seeing what everyone else was eating! 

We stalked a few people finishing up their meal so we could get a seat. 

I didn't get a receipt and I was like how do they know what food I got, or where we sat, or that we were seated inside. 

But I didn't know that this was a magic place, with great, reasonable food, and workers that actually knew what they were doing and remembered everything. 

They brought out food out to us, even the stuff we ordered after we sat. Their staff is also fast with clearing/cleaning table so everyone can get in and out. 

All our silong's were great and not greasy, filling, and fresh! Good garlic rice and meats.

I will for sure be coming back here!!
author: Derek S.

description:
Yes, it's a no non-sense dive.  Most people order to-go.   Most expensive rice plate on the menu costs $3.99, and that's for fish!  Filipino breakfast rice plates include garlic fried rice, one egg over-easy, tomato or pineapple chunks, and your choice of meat.  One plate is good for 2-3 meals!!!  

Meat choices:
Tocino (sweet cured pork)
Tapa (beef cooked in vinegar)
Fried JUMBO chicken quarter (so crunchy, so huge)
Longganisa (Filipino-style pork sausage)
Porkchop (fried)
Hong Kong style Pork chop (battered and fried, and my mom's favorite)
Hotdog
Spam
Whole fried tilapia
Daing (fish marinated in vinegar, garlic, salt, and pepper, then dried, and fried)
Tuyo (dried herring)
Smoked fried bangus whole (Bangus - Milkfish)
Smoked fried half boneless bangus from a huge fish (my absolute fave...I always order the head part since I love the bangus belly)
Smoked galunggong (Mackarel Scad - my second favorite)
Bangus sisig ( it's good but not my fave, I like my sisig grilled but theirs is pan-cooked)
They also have a lot more choices but I can't remember them all!

Lady in the front is friendly remembers the regulars' orders.  She knows I luv fish so she always lets me know when they have something new.
author: Bernadette G.

description: I have been coming here since 1993. This place is affordable and my fave is their tapsilog.  This place gets really crowded sometimes so I always order mine take out.
author: Jingle A.

description:
It's a Chinese-Filipino fusion dream team! 

It's as if a broke Filipino cook lived in Chinatown district for said how many years and finally, after discovering the best types of dishes combined with cheap effective ingredients, moved over to the Mission district, paid a $500 renting deposit, and set up this little hole in the wall. 

True story? Nah, but it is how it is.

The food here is cheap, dirt cheap! and you get more than what you pay for. For about $4, you get garlic fried rice topped with pinapple (the Filipino kick), a sunny side up egg, your choice of the meat, and soup (also a drink too I believe). 

Are you serious? Hell yeah I am! So what if it's a little dirty and looks a little ghetto! If your reading this review, I know your broke so save yourself some time and money and fill yourself up without even breaking a 5!
author: Albert L.

description: Place was small but food was great.  Definitely a hole in the wall food place.
author: Reggie S.

description:
2.5 Stars

First time coming here. 

Porkchops: over cooked and dried
Popcorn chicken: Not too bad
Sausage links: Really good, but they only give you two small pieces.

All came with "fried" rice, egg and either pineapple or tomatoes. 
Our came with pineapples and they were yummy, couldn't get enough. It was not too sweet or tart, just the way I like it.

All under $10! 

For around $3 each , it's pretty worth it. I'm disappointed that they over cooked the pork, otherwise it would have not tasted as chewy.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Store looks like crap, workers look Chinese but speak Togalog, food is good,
price is right. Hong Kong style pork chop over garlic rice for less than 5 dollars.
Gotta love it!
author: Wilson Z.

description:
I came here at 1:30 on a Wednesday, and there was actually a small line forming inside! There were people sitting down and eating too. :) 

It took me a while to figure out what to get, since there were a lot of choices. I read Yelp reviews before I came and I was thinking about getting the HK Pork Chop, but I figured that I might as well try something new.

I ordered the Tapsilog. It came out to $3.25, and I spoke to the cashier in Cantonese. She was really accommodating and nice, and made sure that my friend and I understood what every dish was. 

I didn't get to eat the Topsilog that my friend ordered, but my Tapsilog was amazing. There was less beef than I expected, but the sauce was somewhat spicy (to me) and salty, but there was a lot of garlic fried rice. The egg was done nicely - not too runny and not too solid. I got pineapple and it was just... pineapple from a can. Can't expect too much. The rice actually didn't taste like garlic. I was kind of disappointed, to be quite honest! I would have liked a small hint of garlic somewhere, but that wasn't the case. However, the rice was cooked well and it was good. 

Four stars. Honestly, the food was cheap enough to make up for some of the oversights - i.e. the rice with no garlic taste and the lack of beef - because it came quickly, tea was good (and came with the meal). 

I actually came back here after this visit and ordered the HK Pork Chop and it was HUGE. However, the rice that time was leftover (I got it to go), since it was harder and  eh. But I got tomato this time and was surprised to see that it was raw. It was soooo good. The only downfall was the rice, but again, for $3.50 or so? I can't complain.

Will definitely come back a third time. Hey, who can pass this place up?
author: Nancy C.

description: Love it.. Original prices and portions.. Can't ever go wrong with this place.. If you're near by you must come here for a good Asian/Filipino breakfast.
author: David C.

description:
Superstar is a great place to go for some cheap Filipino food.

I dined in here a few times, but I wouldn't recommend it. The tables and chairs feel really old and dirty. Nowadays I just come here to order take out.

At certain times of the day, especially around the lunch hours, the place is packed. Many people are in there dining and many people are ordering to go. If you are ordering to go, I suggest calling in ahead of time to place your order. They make your food pretty quick.

They serve Filipino and Chinese food. I never tried their Chinese food because I am so satisfied with the taste of their Filipino food.

I ordered their Fried chicken leg before, but it's so oily, I wouldn't order it again. I usually stick with my regular, which is Tocino. I love the meat and it's very cheap ($3.25).
author: Jenny T.

description:
Superstar is SUPER dirt cheap.

I have no idea if I have been tricked into thinking the food is delicious because of its bottomless-pit low prices, but I don't care!

The meats are greasy or deep-fried (two giant pork chops are my favorite), the garlic rice is somewhat lacking in flavor and bereft of actual garlic pieces, and the veggies seem decently fresh.  There is no way I can complain when all of that comes in a regular-sized takeout box at around $3!

This is not a place to plan a proposal, but it's great for just about everything else.
author: Andrew M.

description: Ah Superstar. How you're always the Plan C to everyone's kick it spot after seven periods of school. I can't thank Jeff and the rest of his family for all the meals and smiles they have given me. Okay, here's the rundown: Silogs-cheap, Service-good for what it is, Facility-Err.., Parking-Street or Safeway. This place will always have a place in my heart.
author: Christian F.

description: Food is great. Came here in the gold old high school days. Not the prettiest but the food is decent and cheap. If you are on a budget this is your spot.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
My Ratings:
Quantity: 4 - Plenty!
Quality: 4 - Yum!
Price: 5 - Cheap!
Location: 2 - Closet space with several chairs
Parking: 2 - Metered Street Parking 
Service: 4 - Friendly
Speed: 4 - Fast

Overall: If I'm in the area, this is for sure the place where I'll get my silog. I can try all of their silogs and still have enough for gas. It's that cheap.

My Opinion/Story:
I think if you order their Fried Chicken or their PorkChops, it's sooo worth the money. But if you get their tosino or longanisa, you get only a few pieces but still good.  I won't complain about their longsilog and tosilog since both are only $2.75 each. You only see that price at Costco or you get 2 tacos for that price.  Their fried rice is done right without the overwhelming garlic and you get one egg. Minus one star for their questionable water and coffee. 

I suggest you B.Y.O.Drinks.
author: Cherryl D.

description:
The first time that I came here, I was so surprised at the price, it's soooooo cheap, it's half a price you would normally pay for entree and side. $2.75 for longanisa combo and about $3.50? Cant remember, but definitely less that $4 For their hugeeee pork chops. If only I live nearby, I'll have that 3-4 times a week. 

The parking is hard but it's worth to wait for. I'm suprised tho, every time we get there, we find parking. Depending on how lucky you are I guess. 

I remember when i would skip class just to get food there, once in a while.
author: Wendy Z.

description:
What more can u expect!
1. GOOD FILIPINO BREAKFAST
2. COMPLETE MEAL
3. BIG ASS PORTION
4. CHEAP ASS PRICES
5. ALOT OF OPTIONS
6. FREINDLY SERVICE

JEFF KEEPS THE RESTAURANT BUMPIN AND UP FROM HIS GOOD SERVICE!
author: Brian E.

description: Love the debone bang us fish & Hong Kong style pork chops!
author: Mao X.

description:
Great Value. Food is very good for what you're paying. 

From my understanding is cash only. 

The place is a bit rundown but I personally believe it's part of the flare. It's a no nonsense food place. The place still scores 90+ by the food inspector so the place is clean.

My only suggestion is to have more choices in vegetables besides tomatoes/pineapples. Just a personal reference. 

Def go this place a shot. Parking is a bit tricky if you're driving there.
author: Steven Z.

description:
where do you go to feed two hungover adults a filling breakfast for under $10, whose name doesn`t start with Mc, is a King, or lives in a Box?

SUPERSTAR!! [even the name sounds promising!]

this place may be a dirty, greasy hole in the wall, but in my experience hole in the walls always have the BEST food.  some of the best food in the city can be found in hole in the walls in Chinatown, TL, and North Beach [just to name a few].  all i know is, the layer of griminess must add that extra OOMPH to make food oh so delicious!  

you definitely CAN`T beat the price either!  for $3.25, you get two HUGE HK-style fried pork chops, a mound of garlic rice, an over-easy egg, and a choice of tomato or pineapple chunks.  the pork chops were crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside.  the garlic rice was savory and aromatic, with bits of toasted garlic in every bite.  booboo ordered the fried chicken leg, which was the size of one of my pomeranians!  it was very juicy and flavorful.  however, i found it a bit odd that pineapples were an option to be included with my meal...i suppose you need something vegetable-ly to cut through the grease and luckily for them, i hate tomatoes but love pineapples! LoLx

seating is pretty limited and it gets busy quick, so my suggestion is to order to go.  it`s too bad they`re only open for breakfast and lunch, because i would lovee to come here for filipino breakfast at 3AM after a night of drinking and partying!  oh well, i guess that`s where ling nam or colma cafe come in... :x

booboo and i got 2 plates of food and two cans of soda, all for around $9.85!  being Asian, i lovee a good deal!  we`ll definitely be back time and time again for some awesomee cheap eats!
author: Dee W.

description: First thing everyone needs to do is look at the menu that is taped onto the counter and not the one above on the menuboard. The best food here is the jumbo chicken and Hong Kong Pork Chop. You can't get this portion anywhere else with this price. For the others such as Longsilog, the portions are rather small compare to the jumbo chicken and hong kong pork chop, but again you cant beat the price!
author: Wilson P.

description:
I was born to eat at this place. 

This place was opened to feed me.

I'm so glad we finally met.

Superstar I love you, and I will always love you.
author: Spencer W.

description: Super star is a hole in the wall type of eatery on Mission street  that has a sign over the door stating Chinese food to go but it really specializes in Philippino style cooking and for the price and quality of food it's a YuMMy deal. My picky Americanized kids love the garlic fried rice and always mix the semi-soft fried egg over the dish. They offer a choice of  chopped tomato or pineapple bits and for the main course my wife like the fried bangus (called milk fish) and I like the toncino or the fried chicken...The list of food options goes on and on with even Spam on the menu! In our household when we suggest Super Star everyone will show up at the table. I think I'll fire up the jeepney and visit them today.
author: Royce B.

description: If you're looking for cheap and fast filipino food this is the place. But the place looks very dirty and disgusting.  I usually just order to go. It would be nice if they could remodel the place of at least paint the walls. There's tagging and cravings all over the place.
author: Betsy X.

description:
This place is HELLA dirty. It's cheap, which is always a plus; but it's GRIMEY.

I got food poisoning. I hate them.
author: Erica A.

description:
BIG SERVINGS.
Love the hongkong style porkchops with garlic rice, egg and pineapple slices.
But to attract more customers, they should clean the restaurant because it looks dirty.
author: Dee S.

description:
Heart-attacks for snacks? Nah, breakfast for champions! 

After a long night of drinking and watching people throw up out of every window of an 11th floor apartment building, it sounds about right that you would need to re-fuel and re-energize. 

The perfect hangover remedy? Superstar!!!

HONG-KONG STYLE PORK CHOPS. I would say "enough said", but for those who have never had Superstar you're probably like "ZUH?"

My suggestion: Hong Kong Style (Deep fried) pork chops on a bed of garlic rice and a couple pieces of tomatoes or pineapple (depending on what location you go to). Pair this with some Filipino style vinegar and you have a match made in heaven! Let's not forget to mention that you get all of this for $4. It's bomb.com/nomnomnom

It's probably not the healthiest of things, but it's soo tasty! Especially if you've been killing your taste buds with tequila and stomach acid. 

This place is definitely a hole in the wall, but it's definitely worth the try. 
"Superstar" is not easily seen - the bigger sign says "Chinese Food" so keep your eyes peeled. Also bring cash and get there before 3:30/4:00 because they close early.
author: Ashley C.

description:
The doors of the Super Star Restaurant open into a dingy looking space.  Sheetrock walls cry out in vain for a fresh coat of paint, while fake walnut paneling along the north wall is loaded with carved sets of initials that pre-date the Reagan administration. Two windows face Mission Street, but fliers, pamplets, and advertisements hinder any light trying to get in.

While ambiance is lacking, the grub isn't bad.  The sound of orders sizzling on the grill radiates through dining area, and no steam trays are visible from the counter.  Better yet, everything on the menu is under five bucks, with the vast majority of combination plates selling for under four.

I got the Mongolian Beef, which came with alongside a sizable pile of steamed rice. Bargain-priced at $3.95, it was mildly spiced and unconventionally sweet.  While the super-star's rendition of Mongolian Beef is anything but conventional, it's still tasty.  One might even think of it as Szechwan-Filipino fusion instead of the generic Mandarin you might expect.  The staff is friendly and polite, and despite the wear-and-tear on the interior, the entire place looks pretty clean.

Unless you find yourself deep in the outer Mission, the Super Star isn't a destination that's worthy of inter-neighborhood travel.  But if you're in the Excelsior and not far from Geneva, stop by if ambiance is something you'll sacrifice for decent Chinese food at rock-bottom prices.
author: Mike W.

description:
What makes this place great is the very affordable prices.

Parking is a hassle.

Try to pre-order before u get there or you'll be standing in line.

Service is quick and friendly.

Downside to this place is and I hope they read this review is they need to clean up the place. Greasy chairs and table.

All in all, I love this place....you can't go wrong in whatever you decide to eat.
author: Michael m.

description:
This restaurant is not only a place to eat, but holds something much more valuable. I remember being a kid, and waking up to these styrofoam takeout boxes with happy faces on them on the kitchen table. My dad would get home from work at 9am, and always bring me and my big sister some food for us to eat. So I guess it's safe to say I was brought up with this food, and I still love it to this day.

The place, as far as I can remember, has the same cashier guy, dealing with all the customers. He is truly a nice guy, and I always let him know I was a kid when I first saw him. 

The food is what's special about this place. Very simple filipino/chinese plates that are extremely cheap. They range from about $2 to $3, from tosilog to longsilog, to new plates they have introduced. The plates usually come with either tomato  or pineapple slices, and an "eeg". Some of the regulars might remember this, but they used to have a wooden board that said "blah blah blah w/ eeg". They misspelled egg wrong and it always caught my eye. Anyways, this is place very old, and has had the same layout since my early years. I hope the business continues to prosper, as I would be truly saddened if they ever decided to close. Long live SUPERSTAR!
author: Chris E.

description: This is a hole in the wall restaurant with some really good Filipino food made by Chinese people!  All the meals are less than $4.00!  ITS SO GOOD.  I ordered the Longsilog, which came with two sausages, garlic rice, and sunny side up eggs.  MAN. So SIMPLE, but SO.. GOOD.  Everything was on point and its so damn cheap!  Next time i visit the bay, I'm definitely coming back.
author: Allen P.

description:
I love this place! I went here 3 years ago with my boyfriend, but I've known about it since high school because my friends used to hang here. Jeff always knows our orders because we always call in advance.

Love the: Hong Kong Style Pork Chops, over easy eggs and pineapples mixed in the rice, the tocino, and longanisa all at very reasonable prices! Being filipino, people of my culture who own restaurants ALWAYS overprice food, and I'm glad Superstar makes the meals cheap.
author: Ruby E.

description: This place is bomb. I've been coming here since 2008. I usaully get the tocino which comes with garlic rice, eggs, and your choice of either pineapple or tomato. Order to go if theres nowhere to sit down and eat :) Its usually packed.
author: Yeni K.

description: Real good food.. Soooo cheap too.. Fast service.. This is my dad's fave restaurant every time he visits the US.. He is friends with "Jeff" now:)
author: Annabizelle D.

description:
Yes, this place is dirty as hell and stagnant of old chinese food. I can't stand eating my food at this spot; the silverware is never clean, the tables have that sticky feel to them (it makes me cringe to even think of what lurks beneath the tables) and the thought of "How sanitary is this place?" ALWAYS pops up in my mind.

But tell me why you can get a fresh WHOLE fried tilapia, fried rice, eggs and tomato for less that $4?? Or a hearty plate of Longsilog or Topsilog for less than $3?? No matter how dirty this place is, the quality of the food and the price keeps me coming back whenever I'm in town. 

This place reigns supreme when it comes down to a poor man's breakfast.
author: Elijah A.

description:
Ah this place! I remember going here when I was young and ordering chickensilogs almost everyday. Probably explains why I was so obese.

Anyways! Fast forward to today. A broke college student has to eat somehow! Thank God for Superstar! 

Parking can be a pain but Safeway is across the street so just park your car over there and jaywalk on to the other side. This place is truly a hole in the wall. It's so old and really grimey. The floors are dirty and it seems as if no one buses the tables, which is why I get my food to go. But once you overlook the aesthetic qualities of Superstar, you'll find that their food is truly what makes them.

Plus one for the man who takes my orders! He's always so nice and seems like he enjoys his job. :) The silogs are freaking $3 man! My favorite, the longsilog is always perfect! The egg looks so smooth and the tomatoes are fresh. The longanisa is amazing! The fried rice is okay.. I've had better but hey! It's freaking $3!

They're always busy no matter what time of the day I go. Minus one star for cleanliness though.

Hole in the wall and cheap eats, go to Super Star!
author: Joyce E.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall, just the way I like it.

I always go for tapa (beef) when I'm trying to get my silog (garlic rice & egg) fix, and this place serves up a great one for hella cheap. Only $3.25!

Unlike other places that serve tapsilog, their marinade has that distinct sour, almost vinegar-like aftertaste which takes some getting used to, but still good altogether.
author: Juno M.

description:
I would give it 5 but let's be honest it's a bit pokie looking. 

Four stars for amazing amazing food!
Prices are unbelievable! 
And service is good as well. 

Hong Kong Pork Chops are always a must and you can't complain about the place when you have big excellent porkchops for 3 dollars in front of you. 


Hole-in-the-wall. Great food:) love it.
author: Shelly M.

description:
The first time I went here I was a bit skeptical. It looked grimy, it smelled like the Philippines, parking on a steep hill was stressful, and the business had a menu board displaying Chinese cuisine which no one ever ordered from, but I just had to give the $3 silogs a try. Mmmm, and from the greasy goodness of the hong kong style spareribs, to the garlic fried rice and pineapples on the side, I fell in love with this deliciously cheap hole in the wall!

My friend and I took our orders one time to fort funston for a little picnic and there was this cute stray dog that was just staring at us. We looked away for a quick while over to the hang gliders and before we could even run away, the dog took hold of my friend's pork chop. 

Superstar is yummy, and apparently the dog thinks so too.
author: May D.

description:
OK so I know we are trying to eat better for ourselves in this new year but I can never turn away this place and it's counter part. I dont eat pork so that takes most of the menu away for me. However I do not mind. I always order the fried chicken and man it is worth every greasy bite. you pay $3.40 for a huge mound of garlic fried rice, a sunny side up egg, and pineapple chunk then a large serving of yummy fried chicken.

I will say that this is a great place to go when you hung over and want some greasy food.

Oh how I love you Superstar, just wish you were open late night
author: Lisa W.

description:
Cheap, fast, delicious Filipino food!

Hong Kong Style Pork Chops = delicious, melt in your mouth.
Tosino, longanisa, bangus, fried rice = all delicious!

Make sure you get here early on weekends, otherwise it gets bust fast.  

Definitely a whole in the wall kind of place, may look grimy at times (especially small kitchen) but do not think much of it.  Food is good!!

How much better can it get to get meat, rice, egg, tomato for less than $4?! YUMMY!
author: Lisa T.

description:
CED:  Describe this place in 3 words:  Cheap, great, and portions.  Came here right before going to a theme park, it was the greatest decision.   haha.  So if you're hungry for some great breakfast, just go here if your in the area; or take it to-go.  

Pros:
-SO cheap
-Decent portions
-Taste goooood
Cons:
-Small place
author: Cedric R.

description:
This place is the true definition of a hole in the wall. It's right across the street from the Safeway on Mission, right off of Geneva and when you look at it, it's looks like a random crappy Chinese restaurant and I'm not going to lie, the inside doesn't change that opinion. 

HOWEVER, the menu is LEGIT! It is a Chinese restaurant, but I have always gone for the Filipino food. IT'S SO CHEAP AND DELICIOUS!! I usually order the Longganisa and it comes with a heaping pile of garlic rice, pineapple slices and an egg and it's only like $3!!! I HIGHLY recommend the fried chicken too. Once you go, you will be hooked, no joke!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Yes the food is fried and greasy but it's GOOD and it's CHEAP. 

Get the HK style porkchops and call it a day.
author: mino b.

description:
The definition of hole in the wall.  Ridiculously inexpensive pilipino comport pood, Superstar kept me going in my early starving-college-student days at CCSF.

The Tocilog rocks, and do yourself a favor and get it to go.  There's an absolutely disgusting ghetto ambiance to this place that for anywhere else I'd dock at least two stars!  But here a charming part of the experience is taking it home and eating straight out of the styrofoam carton.
author: Gary D.

description:
Been coming here since my middle school days. Which is over a decade ago for 2 reasons.
1.) Quantity and quality of food.
2.) Price. Best bang for buck.

You will not notice this place if you dont actively look for it. You can pass by it every time even if you drive by it everyday. It's a classic hole in the wall. Not the cleanest, but thats one of the reason that make it what it is.

They switched owners a few years ago and now they serve classic chinese comfort food along with the Filipino food.

The food is not the healthiest at all, But then again you dont come here for healthy food. 

Classic spot for Filipino and Chinese comfort greasy food in the Excelsior district.
author: U L.

description:
Tb comes here sometimes while I go the other one. 

But for lunch today we came here,

We both ordered Bangsilog plus longonisa for him and Tocino for me.

I should have taken a picture of our plates because, we wiped it out...lol.

if you need your PINOY SILOG fix...come here.
author: Malou C.

description:
this hole in the wall restaurant is filled with artery clogging goodness for just $3!

it seriously can't get any better than $3.  When ever i'm in san francisco i ALWAYS try to make a stop here.  All combo plates come withgarlic rice, an over easy egg, your choice of meat and either tomato or pineapples.  the pork chops hong kong style are the best way to go.  you always get atleast 2 large pieces, sometimes even 3 pieces.  It's more than enough to fill any appetite. 

personal preference- the pork chops are the best way to go (hk style). the chicken is a good size and less greasy.  the beef tapa is so-so, and the bangus is just like any other bangus.  they have other breakfast foods 'silog' style, but i personally dont eat breakfast so i've never ordered it.
  
down side about this place is that there is no personal parking spaces, but you can always park across the street at safeway.  the venue is also quite small so it's not too good for big groups.  seating is very limited, which is why you can always order togo.
author: Cheryl E.

description: Good, cheap eats. Not stellar or special but not bad at all. It gets the job done. Def a hole-in-the-wall spot that is good when you just want something and anything to eat.
author: Vincent L.

description: I have been going here for over 15 years now and it's STILL the best!!  I tried Gateway Kitchen in Daly City and no, they aren't the same.  The prices here are still low and the food tastes as good as it did back then.  I love their garlic fried rice, the tapa and the pork chops.  I also had their tocino and I like it too but prefer the tapa. I always get pineapple with mine, too. The people that work there are also nice.
author: Michelle H.

description: I've been coming here since I first moved to SF, 10 years. Their prices are awesome compared to other locations that serve the same type of food. The PORTION of the food is more than enough! The owners are so sweet. Please don't be fooled by how the outside looks, this place is worth your money! I have been coming here for years and will never stop!
author: Wonderful L.

description:
Where else can you get a meal for $2.76?!  And the plate isn't skimpy either.  I had a tuyosilog (with at least 5 pcs of fish), garlic fried rice & tomatoes (you can also get pineapple instead of tomatoes).  

The place is really small & grimy.  I don't think I can take my mom here for lunch, she'll be disgusted.  And this a cash-only establishment.
author: Jo B.

description:
excellent dirt CHEAP filipino food.  they got all the choices and some chinese food up on that menu as well.  if you got $1.95+tax you can get garlic rice, an entree and some egg/tomato.  it WILL fill you up, no doubt.

one of the stars is gone due to parking, cleanliness, and lack of seating.

but stand in line, pay, and take it home to enjoy.  and then you'll know why this place gets the 4 stars ... at least.
author: Pia V.

description:
So, I just had some today for lunch. haha. 

It's really cheap and you get a bunch of food. The food is good for the cost. the silogs always comes with an egg, garlic rice, and either pineapple/tomatoes. I'm half filipino, and i think I've pretty much tried most of the filipino silog things there - longanisa, toyo, bangus, porkchop, chicken, etc. 

I wouldn't sit in at this place though b/c it's really small and it's dirty. The best way to go is to take out. It's hard to find parking, if anything you could probably get away with parking at safeway across the street. Good place to get cheap, fried, greasy chinese/filipino food.
author: Breniel L.

description:
Super Star has been along time favorite of ours in the "E".Food is cheap,quick service and great price.A nice Chinese/American family preparing some simple Filipino dishes.The tosilog,longsilog and Sarangani bangus are so sarap.It reminds me of Gen San.
Gen San is the tuna capitol of the P.I, It is also the hometown of Manny P.
Be prepared to wait a few minutes for your favorite meal,but it is woth it.
You will see regulars every morning seating at the usual table sharing good conversation and food.What more can you ask for in general.
Remember to " Live ,Love and Eat"We hope you enjoy it also.Peace to all.
author: Scott Q.

description: Fair pricing with delicious food. The HK pork Chops are always fresh and crispy and they don't make the food until you order it. Jeff and the aunties are alway nice and courteous. A hole in the wall, but i love the food here and have been a loyal regular there for more than 6 years. Their 50 cent pork and vegi soups are the bomb too.
author: A A.

description:
Herra good!  What that mean?  It means good food for a good price.  I came here after getting hung over for the first time.  It said Filipino restaurant on the sign, but the cashier was speaking Chinese to me.  I was like "Whoa dude, I'm still kind of effed up."  Apparently, I wasn't imagining things though, because I have been here sober as well and the restaurant was still run by Chinese people.  Doesn't matter though, food is food.  These days, people are making other cuisines anyway.  No biggie.  Anyway, back to the restaurant...  
You can't beat the price, quantity and quality.  For under $5, you get a great-tasting meal.  I usually order the Hong Kong-style fried pork chops.  Delish.  I've also had their Fried Chicken and my friends swear by the Longsilog. 
Everything just goes so well together: the fried egg, pineapples or tomatoes, and the GARLIC RICE!  Pour some White vinegar on this, and we're good!
  I'm not Filipino by blood, but every time I come and eat here, I just want to be called the Pacman and knock someone out, sing some karaoke; you get the idea.  
I'm a San Francisco transplant in SoCal now, and for the life of me can't find something similar to Superstar down there.  The first place I call up my friends to go to when I come back to San Francisco is Superstar.  No lie...
The place gets packed quick, so you might have to wait if you're in a big group, which we always come in big groups and haven't had that problem.  Just saying, if you happen to go in a big group and I go with my group, one of us is going to have to wait.  
Parking is street parking.  Either you park on the main street, which are metered or go up the hills to find residential parking.
author: Brandon Y.

description:
Yes, word to the wise, get take out and park on the Safeway lot to save the stress of parking here!  

I'm a fan of this place because it is a true Filipino restaurant with really authentic unhealthy as heck food.  This place is cheap, probably the cheapest place to get Filipino breakfast in all of California though!  The food tastes pretty good too, so it's decent quality.  I particularly like the Tocilog, which is cured pork with rice and eggs.  True Filipino breakfast I tell you... go to Ling Nam and you'll get a better dish, at double the cost!

Maybe we can call this the Little Caesar's of Filipino food?
author: Rodel R.

description: Well what can I say.. 3 bucks for a Filipino breakfast.. can't beat it if your low on moola. Hong Kong style pork chops were not bad at all.. I'd come back here, but if your looking for the ambiance and a place to take a hottie to impress .. this place it not easy on the eyes. Tapsilog w a side of Sabao! Live a little and try this place if you are feeling like a 3 dollar pimp!
author: Winston R.

description:
JUMBO FRIED CHICKEN!

this place is a hole in a wall in the middle of a busy Mission Street! call ahead to place an order because parking is a pain!
author: Karen P.

description: The jumbo chicken was good but  next time i will get the hk style porkchop.. it was good price for food..
author: Wilson W.

description:
MEMORIES of my superstar timeline...

My mom & grandpa first brought me here in the 90's to try their infamous bangus belly, and then during my high school years it evolved into the "local cut-out spot for lunch" and then everyone's favorite became the "Hong Kong Style Pork Chop" which featured 2 chops, each one the size of your face, and it was so crispy yet tender when you bit into it. OH! And the fried rice is topped with crispy minced garlic that crunches in your mouth but isn't too strong or overpowering. 

Over a decade later, Superstar is still serving the same menu, with the same low prices, and they're ALWAYS packed. The only downside is that the environment isnt that clean, you will be sorta suspicious regarding the cleanliness of your food, and it leaves a greasy aftertaste in your mouth that you'll be burping/smelling/re-tasting all day. It's totally budget-friendly, so if you're hungry and broke, this is THE place to go. But I ALWAYS wonder how can they possibly make ANY money selling those gigantic portions at those dirt-cheap prices...
author: Joraine C.

description: if i can give them 10stars i will give them... hong style porkchop is the best and their fried rice is sooo good large serving for $4 what?????? i usually get porkchop and their chicken is really good too..
author: Gladys D.

description: My all time favorite Hole in the Wall place. True the place was dingy and cramped but the food is superb! I live in Livermore but grew up in San Francisco but I always make sure I stop by and take some food home every time im in the area. Very reasonable price for a hefty portion of food. You'll keep coming back.
author: M Rinna B.

description:
I miss those college party nights or should I say the morning afters where we would wake up to stacked boxes of superstar heaven. My awesome friends who weren't KOd would take it upon themselves to venture out and buy stacks of the Honk Kong style Pork chops for the rest of us to wake up to.

The restaurant itself is pretty small and the cleanliness is very questionable. But the meals are only $3 and they pile it high...to the point that the to-go box can barely close. 

The garlic rice can be hard at times and I hate that they replaced the tomatoes with pineapples...but for $3, I'm not complaining. 


This is the best meal to wake up to when you have a throbbing head.
author: Bianca L.

description:
I can't believe it took me 3 years of living practically next door to this place to finally give it a try. I am something of a Filipino food novice- I don't know a bangsilog from a topsilog- and a little scared I'm accidentally going to order balut, but the menu at Super Star helpfully breaks it down in plain English for whyte boyz like myself. You know exactly what kind of deep-fried meat you're going to get. And that seems to be the MO here- deep-fried meat served with a heap of greasy garlic rice, a fried egg, and sliced tomato. 

I had the hong-kong style pork-chop on my first visit. 2 crispy-fried pork-chops w/ rice/egg/tomato for 3$?! That's insanity. Does this place actually make money? Are we sure that's pork underneath that crispy-fried exterior? Do we really care? Whatever it is, it makes an excellent hangover cure, and a very satisfying brunch. Katie H. got the baconsilog which included 7 slices of bacon with rice/egg/tomato for like $2.75. For sheer value that is hard to beat. I will definitely be back to Super Star- after my arteries soften, when I need an infusion of savory greasiness to coax my alcohol-drenched brain cells from their fitful, delirious, morning-after malaise.
author: Brian H.

description: I really don't like eating Flipino food besides my parents cooking cause i'm really picky but this joint was GOOD! i expected this place to be run by filipinos but they're chinese selling filipino food. They sell mostly breakfast foods and their garlic fried rice is BOMB. I love the Hong Kong Style Pork Chop which is HUGE and CRISPY.  I also love how it's so cheap. Me and my boyfriend only spent $6 on food. I hate how it so cramp and everything is breaking apart like their counter in the front.  They even have a sign that says don't eat you're to go boxes inside the resturant which i found pretty funny.
author: Janice V.

description:
My monster-sized pork chops and garlic rice w/ eggs and tomatoes truly hit the spot.

This is truly a hole in the wall type spot...VERY tiny.

You can beat the price though, me and the bf both ate for  under $9!!!
author: Jade B.

description:
There are two places that sell "Filipino breakfasts" for $3 on mission, this spot and at Gateway Kitchen on crocker and mission in Daly City.

Since its so cheap, for a little extra you can combine dishes or ask for an extra egg. I suggest tocino and hong kong style pork chops (deep fried battered fatty pork chops) with an extra egg.

Superstar's garlic rice is too dry and isn't as fresh as Gateway Kitchen's. Other than that the menu/dishes are the same. I still come here though if im closer to it than to Gateway. Cheap is always a plus.
author: Albert B.

description:
I wanted to give this place the respect it deserves.  It is a small spot that keeps it simple and does it right.  I love the garlic rice that comes with all of the Filipino breakfasts (which is good for lunch and dinner too).

This place has been good to me since high school ... I remember buying Tapsilog for $2.11 total.  That's right, $2.11.  I rarely had more than $3 in my pocket ... for the price you pay, this is top notch gourmet dining.  

So, to Superstar, thank you for feeding people at dirt cheap prices.  And thank you, Mission drivers, for not hitting me as I run across the street from the Safeway parking lot.
author: Eric D.

description: this place may look like a hole in the wall but its the BEST hole in the wall to get HK Style Pork Chops and Jumbo Chicken! GOTTA TRY THE CHICKEN! and its cheap and fast too!! i LOVE LOVE LOVE IT
author: Crystal L.

description:
I think the ratings are high because the food is so cheap here. A dish with MEAT [looks like it, has the name of it, tastes sorta like it], a ton of garlic rice, and a fried egg for less than $3? An entire fried tilapia for $4? Where are they getting these ingredients? It doesn't even make sense! The quality is definitely reflective of the price, even though the quantity is not.

I suppose you can come here if you're broke or whatever, but I think for the same, I'd rather get a burger at In-n-Out. For all other silog cravings [silogs aren't exactly healthy as it is], I'll probably go elsewhere. I'm sure the people are nice here. The spot is pretty grimy. You get a lot of food for paying next to nothing. So it's really between MEH and A'IGHT since I'm not overly picky.
author: Tinna H.

description:
First off, I would like to refute all the negative comments about this place...
--You guys complain that the food is greasy... but since when was Filipino food NOT GREASY?  

Anyways,
My family, friends, & I have been coming here since I was BORN.  My brother went to Balboa HS in the early 90's where race wars occurred & all the Filipinos used to be posted at Superstar. Even today, excluding the gang wars, almost EVERY SINGLE BALBOA STUDENT has dined at Superstar. It's tradition =D

Oh, & you can never complain about a $3 meal =)


& PARK AT SAFEWAY ACROSS THE STREET. Save yourself a dollar from the street parking. You can get yourself some sabao or an extra egg or something lol



LAST BUT NOT LEAST,
if you're a bit low on self-esteem just call the number & Jeff would answer the phone, "Hello Superstar, how may I help you?"
--He makes you feel like a SUPERSTAR. lol
author: Kim D.

description:
I went to Balboa High and I remember seeing a lot of people going to either Hawaiian Drive Inn, Dakine, or Superstar. I always went to the first two because I've always heard of Superstar as a Filipino restaurant and I don't really know Filipino food that well.

I actually went in recently and was surprised. The place is literally a hole in the wall and is a typical example of a local greasy spoon Asian-style. The food is quite plentiful and cheap. The restaurant's decor is non-existent because they simply don't have the time to manage it. The restaurant is packed and it seems like they are all locals. It is a favorite amongst Filipinos because I always see a lot of them eating in. The food is prepared really quickly and definitely with its fair share of grease and them some.

Filipino food and Chinese food are both served here and they're both really good. I had the garlic fried rice and it looks like they use an entire clove or two of garlic for the fried rice. Although I may not come back because the hygiene just looks a bit too questionable for me, it was definitely tasty and a good experience.
author: Rick C.

description:
Lunch plates for under $4. My coworkers got me hooked yo this plates by bringing me here years ago. The owner keeps things simple with a simple menu. They're from Hong Kong but they cook select items with Filipino influence. Their sausage rice and fried chicken leg rice are my favorites. On top of that, the rice they serve is garlic fried rice which is great.

The one problem is, since they're close to Balboa High, they get a lot if their students during lunch. Too many of them show disrespect for property by writing on and messing up the restroom wall. I cannot blame the owner for mot improving the decor.
author: H K.

description: Cheap tasty mom and pop shop. Had the HK pork chops and they were good. They give you a huge portion for only $3.50. I couldn't finish it so had the rest for dinner. The meal also comes with tea or coffee.
author: Ayana K.

description:
I can get down with the ghetto!!! 

The food is goooood! I mean for the price and the size of the servings! It's just what we need in this enoconomy. Starving folks - for $5 bucks you'll get a meal with a can of soda.

Hong Kong Style Pork Chops, Bangsilong, Tapsilog with eggs! Ummmm yummy for my tummy. Its comfort food that you have to try. This place doesn't get the award for the best decor, but if you want to fill your tummy with good simple food and generous serving... try them one out!
author: Jules V.

description:
Ok I'm real hesitant on posting a review here because I'm scared this place will start upping it's prices and this great cheap eats place will no longer be that. =\ Oh what the heck.. Yelpers share yes? Here's my hole in the wall place to get to go food. Introduced to me by some friends, they said they could feed me for 3 bucks. In disbelief, they took me to Superstar., We got to go orders of Filipino sausages and rice with egg and veggies for 3 bucks!?!?!?! WTH ummm was I stealing this food? Oh boy 3 bucks?!?! Pricing error? Seriously I didn't get it but whatevers because it smelled so good. We got back home and I opened up my little box of yummy goodness and chopped down. 

Food was delish and price was great. I haven't tried any of their other stuff here but I'm pretty sure I'll be back for some cheap good eats.
author: Allan T.

description:
-1 for having a dirty place.

Other than that...
you are a superstar!!
I have been craving Filipino food for awhile now because I haven't had some since I left home to move here. My cousin told me about this place he said it was really good, he suggested to order the fried chicken.. Ehh I have fried chicken all the time so I decided to try another meal I ordered a bansilog meaning bangus (fish),garlic rice, tomato and eggs. I lalalove it! Makes me miss my grandma's cooking. My cousin got the chicken and it was huge! This place is pretty cheap too! $3 each and it comes with all of this! 
Total: 8.50! For two meals. Goodbye mcdonalds mini meal!
Yepp. :)
author: Anna P.

description:
4 stars for the delicious food and super fast service. Seriously, me and my bf only had to wait like less than 5 minutes and our food was done! Good thing too because I was STARVING!

My favorite here is the Hong Kong Style Pork Chop-silog. I get 2 humongous porkchops, a big helping of rice, an egg sunny side up, and diced tomatoes. All this for $3-4!!!

The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because the place is a little dirty. I guess since their food's so cheap they don't have enough money for repairs.

For anyone wondering, they DID pass through the health inspector. They've made some sanitary improvements to the place so I think their score went up. I saw their food score card displayed in the glass counter and THEY PASSED.
author: Jane C.

description:
ok I used to visit this spot regularly in my teens would of given it a 5 star rating then simply because of the quantity and the cost. haha been back recently the food is still the same quantity of quality and cheap as hell.

not a spot to take a date or maybe haha, but if you want something fried or have that itch for some cheap filipino if not chinese food this is the spot to hit up.. I prefer the silog plates that is just me, large deep fried pork chops, tocino (cured sweet pork), longinisa (sweetened filipino sausage), chicken and several other choices that come with garlic rice and i think an egg haha.

inside is how do i say dirty in a nice way haha, runned down chinese restuarant that serves filipino food which is wierd but they make it work

food *** for quantity 5 stars easy quality maybe just a 3
price $ dirt cheap u can pay for yourself, a friend, a friend of a friend, and a cousin and still have change from a $20
ambiance umm no stars
author: Clarence A.

description:
Smoked Bangus with egg and rice for under $4?
3 combo meals for under $10?

The is like a club line leading to some oh-so-bad-for-you greasy, fatty goodness. Well the garlic rice isn't greasy, and the bangus is boneless and good size.

I don't eat here, just because its always packed and comes off grimy but I love the prices - and we all know that janky-ass spots that stay open for years and years got it going on. Um, the tocino is fatty, but what can I expect for a $3 meal with a few chunks of canned pineapple?

And the food comes out quick, flash fried, and I know they must have the rice constantly going...
author: Cheryl D.

description:
4.5 Stars.


this place is pretty much a hole in the wall.

you get what you pay for. and the portions do not disappoint.

i got the hong kong style pork chop breakfast, and tho it was a bit greasy, it filled me up, and if you're broke and have only $3, you really can't complain, and it doesn't even taste bad at all.

its all about the value here. its good to your pockets.

they should really open up one in downtown san jose. this place could make bank, especially if open late.
author: Phil T.

description:
Now this is the place to go if you're B.O.B....a baller on a budget. This hole in the wall serves up huge helpings of either chinese or filipino breakfast food at rock bottom prices. My absolute favorite is the Hong Kong Style Pork Chopsilog...it's great! Battered and fried pork chop, fried rice and a fried egg....usually comes with tomatoes or slices of pineapple as well...but as far as I'm concerned that's just garnish.

Come here if you're feeling the pinch of the recession.
author: Derrek O.

description:
Superstar where all the cheap, broke, ghetto folks enjoy eating Filipino/Chinese food

Been coming to this place for 10 years now.

I tried the Reg Pork Chop, HK Pork Chop, Tapa, longansis, milk fish, and tocino. All of them are great especially the price! Yes it is Chinese run but they can cook a mean meal for hecka cheap.

Funny after many years, I still have not dine in this nasty place. I mostly see old Filipino folks enjoying eating in.
author: DVS A.

description: OMG this place is so cheap! Breakfast for under $3! I live in Carson and you can't get a Filipino breakfast here for that price.  We stop here for a quick breakfast before exploring the city. We got the Tocino and the Longanisa breakfast both for about $6 including tax! The longanisa and tocino breakfast comes with a huge scoop of garlic rice, an egg, and pineapple or tomato. Yes this place is a total hole and the wall and it doesn't look that clean but the food is decent for the price.
author: Erica C.

description:
With all the reviews already written about Superstar, this one will be another one of those that raves about the decent food for an affordable price. I've been here several times since being introduced to this place last year, and I still can't believe you can get a full meal for less than $3.00. I've had pretty much the main lunch menu....the Tasilog, Longsilog, HK Style Pork Chop, and Fried Fish, and I can vouch for every one of them. 

In a take-out box, they give you a decent portion of the food. The garlic rice, with sprinkles of garlic on top, is probably what will fill you up the most along with a side of fried egg and your choice of either pineapple or tomato. 

This place isn't the most sanitary place on the block, but people seem to love coming here. Because of this, I've only had take-out and those who decided to sit-in seem to enjoy their food regardless of the environment. O well. If I'm in the neighborhood and looking for a cheap lunch (btw... they're only open during lunch hours), I'll be sure to drop by.    

On a side note, you're probably wondering why this Filipino restaurant is owned by a Chinese family. My curious gf asked the woman at the register and she told us that they used to work for a restaurant somewhere else and made Filipino food. So... they probably figured they'll make a pretty good business making their own style of Filipino food.
author: Kenny C.

description:
Filipino Ghetto Food! I love it a LOT! Great price and food! 

Every time I miss eating Tuyo, I'll go over here and eat!
author: Nikkie V.

description:
I was here over a year ago during a trip with one of my girlfriends.  Unfortunately, in my own neighborhood we have very little access to filipino eats because there isn't much of a demographic.

ANYWAYS.

I fixed on some tocino and got my grub on with a group of 8

Incredibly greasy but not at all disappointing.  The place is of course on the dirty side but i didn't come for the ambiance.  I paid my $3 and got what a I paid for.

It's a no nonsense place.  You don't pay for the service or the setting when you're a starving college student.

Perfectly affordable grease.
author: Cayleen O.

description:
My favorite dish here is the Hong Kong Style Pork Chops. Everyone reviews about this dish because it's yummy and filling! It only costs $3.95 plus tax. For the price, it's completely worth it. It comes with the choice of tomatoes and pineapples. I prefer the pineapples over the tomatoes any day. 

The only reason I wouldn't give this place its missing star is because of its presentation. The environment just makes me a little uncomfortable, even though I grew up in the neighborhood. It's not that it's unsafe, I just doesn't feel that clean.
author: Angel V.

description:
Got 3 dollars?  Then come to this dirty ass place.  The walls are gross, the ceiling is gross, and the kitchen looks like a slimy chinatown alleyway.  All the menu items are misspelled or missing letters.  The menu has cheeseburgers, fries, and 95 cent onion rings.  They were out of onion rings indefinitely.  I doubt they have the other items too.  But you're not here for that.

You're here for their 3 dollar filipino breakfasts.  Greasy ass porkchops, 1/4 chicken thigh, or some strange deep fried fish that my co-worker got.  Comes with stale tasting garlic rice, a lightly fried egg and a couple cubes of tomatoes.   Great place to bring your gf if you're low on cash money.
author: daniel l.

description: i came in hungry, can't get out i'm too full. very cheap. thank you superstar for being there to fill our stomachs. been eating here for years and i'm still alive. jeff don't raise your prices.
author: Nelson B.

description:
My friend took me here - a drive from Russian Hill- just to get a filipino style breakfast ie tapsilog... This is the kind of cooking grandma makes back in PI- sweet, spicy langonisas, fried chicken and fried pork chops- think of the equivalent salt and pepper pchops... its good and comes with GARLIC fried rice...oh and suka with peppers as a condiment-- u cant go wrong here...tayo na!

UPDATE- 3/25/2007
I came back recently to check up on the fried chicken- as I remember them being really good- and well I think its good enough to put on my fried chicken list...and well for the price of just over 3 dollars- is quite hard to beat!  Chicken is fried to a delicous golden brown crispy skin and quite tender- its made to order...note this is not the usual batter style y'all r used to- so dont expect that here :-)  I was a little disappointed with the garlic rice- it was on the dry side- meaning it wasnt a fresh batch...boo hoo hoo...
1-Taste/Flavor 7/10
2-Tenderness/Succulence 7/10
3-Crunchy factor 7.5/10
4-Overall appeal 7/10
author: Arissa C.

description:
Who doesn't like cheap food? $3 for a whole plate, who can beat that?

This place is small but it makes up a lot of what they serve. There are many silogs and chinese dishes to choose from. Best place to come here when you wake and bake!

They used to fill up the to go box though ;/
author: Marjorie B.

description:
Super cheap prices means fishy business...

Ate here once with my BF a couple of months ago, with the suggestion of our dear friend. We ordered tapsilog and tosilog. The food came out as expected, greasy and satisfying. When my BF went to the bathroom, he came back with a look of disgust. Turns out they keep their rice and other ingredients stored in bins nicely seated on the WET, GREASY FLOOR. After paying less than $10 for four meals (including 2 take out), we left with a sense of nausea. Not because of the food, but because of what we were gastrointestinally anticipating over the next couple of days. Suffice to say, we were all right.

Though the prices are astronomically cheap, I would have to pass. I would rather pay the extra premium to have my food prepared in a cleaner kitchen environment. I wonder what the Health Inspectors will say when they stop by...
author: Carloalexi M.

description:
I call this place super farts because the unbelievable amount of farting that ensues after eating here. Going back to class after eating here is a BIG mistake; i usually get the cold sweats during class holding it in and dont even think about going here before a test. I guess my stomach isn't used to all that grease 

Nothing beats the price at this place, you get a hearty breakfast which will knock you back to bed after eating this stuff. Their garlic fried rice is the best and nothing beats their tiny over easy "Eeg" (look at the menu) with a side of delicious pineapple. This is really greasy food, but if you're hungry with 5 dollars in your pocket this really hits the spot. 

Yes the place is really run down but for around 3-5 dollars for a huge plate you cant expect much. Nothing beats eating a porkchop with a fork and a spoon (tip: you have to ask for the knife).
author: Eric N.

description:
Yes, it's a hole in the wall. Yes, it's a bit scary. Yes, it's damn good. 

The first time I went, I had to be talked in to ordering. See, I'm not the hole in the wall type, but if you talk me into it, I'll try it. Once you get past the look of the place, the food is actually delicious! This is food like my Grandmother makes it. Good home-style filipino breakfast for cheap! Excellent for the morning after getting really drunk and needing to eat something greasy and good...and you can feed 3 people for under $10.
author: Ron M.

description: Okay, I'm not going to lie, this place is pretty disgustingly dirty compared to these other restaurants in the city. But i would consider this as a hole in the wall type of place. You Can NOT beat the price. 3.50? 3.75? FOR A PLATE OF FOOD?! Are you kidding me?! way cheaper then mcdonalds, or any fast food joint for sure. Especially with the amount of food you get. Only downside is ...its super greasy and fattening. But who cares right? I love filipino  breakfast food, and I always order the hK style porkchop with garlic rice (bomb) and a side of tocino or longanisa.
author: Colette P.

description:
I eat here every so often when I crave for Longsilog.  There fried fish is pretty good also.  

You wont need to eat another meal for the rest of the day, cause its greasy. 

Its a good bang for the buck.
author: Sammy S.

description:
Real delicious and cheap food here.  A small family owned business providing cheap food for the locals.  

Order the fried chicken, with a double scoop of garlic rice.  Its sure to turn that frown upside down.
author: Chai S.

description:
Just a dirty, dirty place.  I just can't stand in there, waiting for my food, while some lady is trying to "tidy up" the already stricken ambiance. I feel like I'm in a horror flick as in the bathroom scene from "Saw". I get fuckin' scared here. 

Though food is decent and cheap, their dirty place can leave more to the imagination. If Super Star possibly raises their food by a buck, they could afford to fix their shabby tables and paint their walls.
author: Eric T.

description:
I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS PLACE. Thanks to a friend introducing this to me, I can't get enough. This is the place to hit up if you're looking for a cheap, but delicious, fulfilling meal. I ALWAYS get the tosino with hong kong style porkchops. My absolute fave.

The place may be run down, and a bit untidy. But go here for the food! They definitely have good service. Nothing but smiles and kindness. It's definitely worth the visit.

Remember cash only!
author: Samantha B.

description:
They open at 8:30 AM. There are usually people waiting around for them to open their doors.
Food is good. It might be a little greasy, but it is Filipino food.
They pretty much specialize in Pinoy style breakfast which comprises of garlic fried rice, egg and a main meat component.

Tagalog Breakfast nomenclature:
fixed component
Itlog, egg, usually fried

variable component
bangus, milk fish
tocino, pork
tapa, beef
spam, processed food product

SImply combine the syllable word for egg, itlog,
with a syllable from the variable component.

For example, Itlog and Bangus
Becomes, Bangsilog.
Which is Fried Rice, Milk Fish and  Egg.

This is pretty standard fare. Good and cheap.
The only caveat, it's a little dirty.
author: Geordie E.

description: My co-worker brought me to this place years ago, food is cheap but good! I always order the tocino w/ Garlic rice, scrambled egg & pineapple, I go here for lunch now & then, the workers are very friendly only thing is that it is literally a hole in the wall! The place is small looks dirty but theyve gotten a good rating as far as an inspection card goes so its safe. Bottom line: It's cheap, good pinoy food!
author: Bobby S.

description:
I haven't been to Superstar in at least 7yrs and had forgotten about the place to be honest until last week.  My brother texted me at 7:30am and  asked if I was awake and if I was interested in having breakfast somewhere. Being that it'd been a while since I had breakfast with him, I decided to get my ass up and join him. 

My brother told me that he wanted to eat at this fancy place called "Stacks" in the Hayes Valley and so that's where we went. We both had the eggs benedict and shared a short stack. It was ok, nothing special. Then came the bill and I saw that my brother paid $60 (including tip)!!!

I laughed and said, "WTF? Did u seriously just pay $60 for breakfast for two?" We walked out and I said, "Thanks Mikey. Tomorrow breakfast is on me. I'm gonna take yo ass to umm...(out of nowhere I remembered) Superstar!" lol Yeah, that's right. Breakfast for two for $8! We both laughed and started reminiscing about the early 90's when we used to go to Superstars (yea, with an "s" at the end!).

The first time I ever ate here was in 1991. My friends and I were freshmens at Balboa High and we'd cut school to go eat here. I remember a skinny chinese guy who every one called "Jeff" behind the counter. I wonder if he's still there? I guess I'll find out today.

But yeah I love this place! Yes it's a hole in the wall, and yes for some people it's not sanitary enough. But I don't give a shit cause the food is great and I've never gotten sick from it. It makes me happy knowing that this place is still around and still serving cheap, tasty filipino/chinese breakfast. Shoot, they even serve fried Tuyo (dried salted fish). You just can't beat that! LOL
author: Johnny T.

description: Truly a hole in the wall. This is the bomb; price, food and even service! lol. Nothing beats the value of food. Love the wide selection of Filipino breakfast and the soup (sabaw) is delicious! Despite the tiny price hike, it's still truly a value! Before to come here early because it can get packed and parking can be an issue.
author: Edgard P.

description: best filipino breakfast ever.. been going here for ~15+ years.. don't knock the atmosphere.. thats not the reason you go here... you go here for the topsilog.. HK Style pork chops... garlic rice is the bomb... bansilog breakfast.. all great..
author: G G.

description: Great for a quick cheap eats when you're hungry and po. Can be a bit greasy but works if you are on the go and need to budget.
author: Ro M.

description:
It's not because I'm Filipino that I'm giving this five stars. Puh-lease, there are plenty of filipino restaurants where I'd give one star or none. 

But their food is delicious as all get out. And cheap. 

And did I mention delicious as all get out?

It's the most random-ass place you can ever find to get some shit, but I love it. All hail to you, Superstar.
author: Thea G.

description:
what i ordered... tocino(sugar cured pork) w/ garlic fried rice and fried egg

i was in the area that i decided to check out the place after more than a decade or two since the last time i've been a customer. low and behold it was still there, including the lines of folks trying to order and to my amazement the unbelievable cost of a meal(a buck more than it used to). Me and ma bud's used to frequent this joint during the times that we were so broke and sometimes we have to walk there to save the paltry muni fair at the time for us to be able to add an extra fried egg to the meal. 

...food was so-so, nothing impressive but descent. at a meager price of $3 you get a full meal that'll really fill you up.

ambiance... bad(just like a hole in a wall chinese restaurant.... oh it is, just that they serve filipino breakfast meals)
service... so-so
cost... $- (it really really can't go cheaper)
author: Gors P.

description:
i've been going to this place since 2005! lol JEFF is the BEST!

$4 H.K. STYLE PORKCHOPS definitely satisfies my fix! whether hungover or just plain damn hungry! 

i know i know, the place is this grimey looking "hole in the wall" but what's new about filipino food coming from a dirty place. i do eat there sometimes, but yeah the sticky tables are gross.

WORD TO THE WISE:  do not, DO NOT, use the chili sauce. lol i've seen shadiest things done to those.  or go to the bathroom, it's just nasty. 

other than that SUPERSTAR is still bomb, no matter how many bad things people say about it. the lines are still long, and forget about seating for parties of 4 or more.
author: tinn r.

description: cheap food but good! plus hella cheap! This joint offers filipino beeakfast food. Meat or fish, fried egg and your choice of tomato or pineapple and garlic fried rice. I always get the hong kong style pork chop and be sure to call in because sometimes they have long line especially lunch hour. This is hole in a wall place thats why i always get mine to go.
author: roderick s.

description:
for the price, this place is pretty good. my sister & I got the hong kong style pork chop plus a drink & it came out to about $4.50 each. portions were HUGE! well for me it was because I ended up having to take half of it home & had it for dinner. overall, if you're in the area and on a tight budget, this place is worth trying. 

minus 1 star for the cleanliness of the store
author: melanie c.

description:
If you like a ghetto surrounding, if your filipino, if your wearing chinelas, if your cheap, this is the place for you!!!! Almost every dish is less than three dollars and nothing will go over $5. The quality of the food is good for its price. The fried rice, with egg and your choice of bangus, tocino, longanisa, etc etc cant be beat. Its traditional filipino breakfast that gives you a feeling of being home, especially if your from the excelsior/mission district.

5 stars for superstar!
author: AimFee G.

description:
I used to eat at this place all the time during high school when I still hung around in SF. I give this place 4 stars because the food is simply amazing for the amount you pay. Sure it's a potential heart attack, and yes the place itself is literally a hole in a wall, however you can't complain if you like fatty foods in big portions like me. A guy's gotta eat, so this is good when you're too lazy to cook or just want some fast grub that isn't your normal Burger King / McDonalds.

I love their tocino, longsilog, and their pork chop dishes. I recommend this place if you're ordering to go, otherwise save yourself the trip because eating there is disgusting.

Haven't been in SF in ages, I miss this place.
author: Jamie C.

description: Cant beat the price and the quality of food you get. For 3 bucks you can get full pretty easily. This place isn't known for it's ambiance and does look pretty Crappy but don't let it's looks distract you from this amazing deal and hole in the wall joint
author: Robert gene R.

description:
you get a plate of filipino breakfast for less than $3 thats actually good
i always add extras to my plate like 
extra egg & extra meat and i always get a soup for 50 cents with it also
comes out to be around 6 dollars.
author: Kenneth C.

description: I love this place! Price was affordable, great food and the garlic rice was delicious as well as the jumbo fried chicken I normally get. Definitely a place everyone should check out, you won't regret it.
author: Jewels Y.

description: Ok so I was told about this place from a couple of cousins that are from the Daly city area.  Wow this place is cheap for what it is and the portions are a lot. You can't go wrong with the price. I guess they have a similar place located somewhere else in the Daly city area.  So my friend Mark and I decided to hit place up.  Right when we walked it was cramped with a bunch of stains in the ceiling and walls.  The place is really small for being a hole in the wall joint.  I got the hong kong style pork chop which was $3.25. Damn that's cheap.  The reason why I gave this place a two star is because of the cleanliness but I should be giving it a one but I'm being nice.  So I saw one of the ladies who was cleaning the place was busing tables out in the dining area.  She had these rubbermaid yellow cleaning glove on.  After that she went to the back making the fried rice.  She had the same rubbermaid glove on one and was mixing the fried rice with the same gloves on!!!!!! After that I stop eating my food and was just in shock! I told my Mark what I just saw and we both left.  I know a lot of people like this place for being cheap but the owners need to check their  employees!  Yuck!
author: Chris P.

description: Superstar is another hole-in-the-wall fave. This is definitely a perfect Filipino style breakfast spot. They had an array of -silog choices. They pack on the garlic rice & serve it with pineapple, which is new because I've always had these types of dishes serve with a side of tomatoes or other veggies. I had the lon-silog (longanisa) & my friend had the top-silog (tocino). We shared a large tea & our meal came out to $6 & some change. It was a good, filling way to start our morning.
author: Kris B.

description:
Holy Shit! This place still exists? Does that skinny chinese dude work at the register still? LOL!

The last time I've been here was almost 8 years ago!! 

The Silogs are cheap, oily, and delicious...just like mom use to make! LOL! I wanna try it again soon!
author: Marc E.

description:
Good stuff!!! If you don't mind the not so clean appearance of a restaurant then close your eyes or have someone order for you... 

the food is delicious and you get a bang for your buck... I been goin since the breakfast silogs were under 2 dollars... Chinese and Filipino Fusion one of da BEST!!!! I have a little creation like that at home my wife and I... 

So the only reason i had to knock off a star was the cleanliness... Yea Jeff, it's ok to wipe things clean and get those windows while you're at it... but if it remains the same... i'm still comin back..
author: Money M.

description: Hello my favorite hangover spot in the city.  Filipino tosilog and lonsilog, garlic fried rice, fried egg.....$2.99.  Large portions, perfect amount of grease to ease the night before.  Neighborhood gem!!!
author: Kim K.

description:
I've been eating at this establishment for 20 years now... and I still enjoy having "ilog" breakfast here, to-go or dine in... To this day, it intrigues me to look at all of the stuff they keep in their display case counter... I guess I am nosey like that, but they seem to have receipts and other pieces of paper there, already tainted in that yellow old-age color... I don't think they've bothered to open up that display case in years... ! Anywhoo, if Superstar wasn't the hole in the wall restaurant that it is, then you'd take away a huge part of the experience (at least in my opinion)...

We usually order the toncilog, tosilog, bansilog (you can ask for which part of the fish that you want btw), tapsilog... and my FAVORITE thing to order is the HONG KONG STYLE pork chop...!
author: Chrysantha C.

description:
OK this was a tough review to write mainly because my breakfast of garlic rice, an "eeg", a sliced tomato, & some meat cost me two dollars and fifty cents. The meal also included table service and coffee/tea.  So the value here is incredible. But I paid $2.50! how much quality can I really expect?!

The food was edible - tasty at best... extremely greasy at worst. Definitely a hole-in-the-wall so if you're into that kind of meal, go for it!
author: Kevan M.

description: Perfect hole in the wall spot.  Their pork chops are awesome.  Either plain or hong kong style.. you will not be disappointed.  Even better that they are served with garlic fried rice.
